Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I had just finished scrubbing the last bathroom, my hands raw from bleach and my back aching. As a housekeeping cleaner, I knew every corner had to shine—no shortcuts, no missed spots. My supervisor expected nothing less, and I took pride in meeting those standards. But today was also Election Day, and I rushed to the polling station, still in my uniform, determined to fulfill my duty as a voter. When I handed in my ballot, the poll worker frowned and pointed out a smudge on the envelope. “You’ll need to re-sign this, please, so your vote counts,” she said. I hesitated, remembering the strict instructions: follow every step exactly, no alterations, or the ballot could be voided. My mind raced—should I trust the poll worker’s guidance, or stick to the official instructions I’d read? The pressure of doing everything “right” in both roles pressed down on me, and I felt torn, caught between the demands of precision and obedience, unsure which expectation to honor.
